{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org\/","@type":"NewsArticle","@id":"https:\/\/cyble.com\/blog\/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat\/#newsarticle","url":"https:\/\/cyble.com\/blog\/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat\/","headline":"Deep Dive Analysis \u2013 Borat RAT | Cyble","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/cyble.com\/blog\/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat\/","datePublished":"2022-03-31T11:08:16-04:00","dateModified":"2025-03-10T05:26:32-04:00","description":"Cyble Research Labs analyzes Borat , a sophisticated RAT variant that boasts a combination of Remote Access Trojan, Spyware, Ransomware and DDoS capabilities.","articleSection":"Trojan","articleBody":"Remote Access Trojan Capable of Conducting Ransomware &amp; DDOS Activities            A Remote Access Trojan or RAT is a tool used by Threat Actors (TAs) to gain full access and remote control on a user's system, including mouse and keyboard control, files access, and network resources access.    During our regular OSINT research, Cyble Research Labs came across a new Remote Access Trojan (RAT) named Borat. Unlike other RATs, the Borat provides Ransomware, DDOS services, etc., to Threat Actors along with usual RAT features, further expanding the malware capabilities.    The developer named this RAT 'Borat' after a black comedy mockumentary film, and the photo used in the RAT is of actor Sacha Baron Cohen, who played the main role in the film Borat. The features claimed by the Borat RAT author are given in Figures 1 &amp; 2 below.    Figure 1: List of Features provided by the Borat RAT    Figure 2: Additional Features provided by Borat RAT    The Borat RAT provides a dashboard to Threat Actors (TAs) to perform RAT activities and also has an option to compile the malware binary for performing DDoS and ransomware attacks on the victim's machine, as shown in Figure 3.    Figure 3: Borat RAT Dashboard    Technical Analysis    In this analysis, we will take a look at Borat RAT and its features in detail. The Borat RAT comes as a package which includes builder binary, supporting modules, server certificate, etc., as shown in Figure 4.    Figure 4: Borat Package    The figure below shows the supporting modules responsible for executing the RAT features, as shown in Figure 5.    Figure 5: DLLs used to execute Features    Keylogger    The module \"keylogger.exe\" is responsible for monitoring and storing the keystrokes in the victim's machine. The below image shows the keyboard-related APIs used by the RAT for keylogging purposes. The captured keystrokes are saved in a file called \"Sa8XOfH1BudXLog.txt\" for exfiltration.    Figure 6: Keyboard APIs    Ransomware    Interestingly, the RAT has an option to deliver a ransomware payload to the victim's machine for encrypting users' files as well as for demanding a ransom. Like other ransomware, this RAT also has the capability to create a ransom note on the victim's machine.    Figure 7: Code to generate Ransom Note    The RAT has the code to decrypt files in the victim's machine once the ransom is paid \u2013 as shown below.    Figure 8: Decryption Method    DDOS    This RAT can also disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server by performing a DDOS attack. The below figure shows the code used by RAT for the DDOS attack.    Figure 9: Code for DDoS Attack    Audio Recording    Borat RAT can record the audio of a computer. Initially, it checks if a microphone is present in the victim's machine. If it can find a connected microphone, the RAT records all audio and saves it in a file named micaudio.wav.    Figure 10: Code for Mic Recording    Webcam Recording    Borat RAT can capture videos through any webcam present in the victim's machine. First, it identifies if a webcam is present in the victim's machine, and then it starts recording the video if a webcam is available. &nbsp;    Figure 11: Webcam Recording    Remote Desktop    This malware takes the remote desktop of the infected machine. It then gives the Threat Actor (TA) the necessary rights to perform activities such as controlling the victim's machine, mouse, keyboard, and capturing the screen. Controlling the victim's machine can allow TAs to perform several activities such as deleting critical files, executing ransomware in the compromised machine, etc. The below figure shows the functions used by the RAT for performing Remote Desktop activities.    Figure 12: Functions used for performing Remote Desktop Activities    Reverse Proxy    The RAT has code to enable reverse proxy for performing RAT activities anonymously. The TAs can hide their identity using this option while communicating with the compromised servers.    Figure 13: Reverse Proxy Code    Device Information    The RAT collects information from the victim's machine, including OS Name, OS Version, System Model, etc. The below figure shows the command used for collecting the information.    Figure 14: Command used for Capturing Device Info    Process hollowing    Using the RAT, the TAs can inject malicious code into the legitimate processes using the process hollowing technique. The below figure shows the APIs used by the RAT for process hollowing.    Figure 15: Process Hollowing    Browser Credential Stealing    Borat RAT can steal cookies, history, bookmarks, saved login credentials from chromium-based browsers like Google Chrome, Edge, etc. The below figure shows the functions used by the RAT for stealing browser credentials.    Figure 16: Functions used for Stealing Browser Credentials    Discord token Stealing:    &nbsp;The RAT also steals Discord tokens and sends the stolen token information to the attacker.    Remote Activities:    The RAT performs the following activities to disturb the victims: Play Audio, Swap Mouse Buttons, Show\/hide the Desktop, Show\/hide the taskbar, Hold Mouse, Enable\/Disable webcam light, Hang System, Monitor Off, Blank screen, etc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;    Conclusion&nbsp;&nbsp;    The Borat RAT is a potent and unique combination of Remote Access Trojan, Spyware, and Ransomware, making it a triple threat to any machine compromised by it. With the capability to record audio and control the webcam and conduct traditional info stealing behavior, Borat is clearly a threat to keep an eye on. The added functionality to carry out DDOS attacks makes this an even more dangerous threat that organizations and individuals need to look out for. The Cyble Research Team is closely monitoring the RAT's actions and will keep informing our clients and people worldwide.    Our Recommendations\u202f&nbsp;    \u200bWe have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the suggestions given below:\u202f&nbsp;     \u200bDon't keep important files in common locations such as the Desktop, My Documents, etc.&nbsp;    Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.\u202f&nbsp;    \u200bTurn on the automatic software update feature on your computer, mobile, and other connected devices wherever possible and pragmatic.\u202f\u202f&nbsp;    \u200bUse a reputed anti-virus and Internet security software package on your connected devices, including PC, laptop, and mobile.\u202f\u202f\u202f\u202f\u202f&nbsp;    \u200bRefrain from opening untrusted links and email attachments without verifying their authenticity.\u202f&nbsp;    Conduct regular backup practices and keep those backups offline or in a separate network.\u202f&nbsp;     MITRE ATT&amp;CK\u00ae Techniques&nbsp;    \u200bTactic&nbsp;\u200bTechnique ID&nbsp;\u200bTechnique Name&nbsp;\u200bExecution&nbsp;\u200bT1204&nbsp;\u200bUser Execution&nbsp;Discovery &nbsp;T1518Security Software DiscoveryT1087Account DiscoveryT1083File and Directory DiscoveryCollectionT1123Audio CaptureT1005Data from Local SystemT1056 .001KeyloggingT1113Screen CaptureT1125Video CaptureCommand and ControlT1132Data EncodingT1219Remote Access SoftwareExfiltrationT1020Automated ExfiltrationImpactT1485Data DestructionT1486Data Encrypted for ImpactT1565Data ManipulationT1499Endpoint Denial of Service    Indicators Of Compromise (IoCs)    \u200bIndicators\u200bIndicator class="elementor-element elementor-element-3c220676 elementor-widget elementor-widget-theme-post-title elementor-page-title elementor-widget-heading" data-id="3c220676" data-element_type="widget" data-widget_type="theme-post-title.default"> <div class="elementor-widget-container"> <h1 class="elementor-heading-title elementor-size-default">Deep Dive Analysis – Borat RAT</h1> </div> </div> <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-1fcc1d6c elementor-widget elementor-widget-theme-post-excerpt" data-id="1fcc1d6c" data-element_type="widget" data-widget_type="theme-post-excerpt.default"> <div class="elementor-widget-container"> Cyble Research Labs analyzes Borat , a sophisticated RAT variant that boasts a combination of Remote Access Trojan, Spyware, Ransomware and DDoS capabilities. </div> </div> <div class="elementor-element elementor-element-2907e1e2 blog_content elementor-widget elementor-widget-theme-post-content" data-id="2907e1e2" data-element_type="widget" data-widget_type="theme-post-content.default"> <div class="elementor-widget-container"> <h2 class="wp-block-heading">Remote Access Trojan Capable of Conducting Ransomware &amp; DDOS Activities</h2><p></p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="790" height="387" data-attachment-id="10345" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/borat/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat.png" data-orig-size="790,387" data-comments-opened="0" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="Borat" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat-300x147.png" data-large-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat.png" alt="Remote Access Trojan Capable of Conducting Ransomware &amp; DDOS Activities" title="Deep Dive Analysis – Borat RAT 18" sizes="(max-width: 790px) 100vw, 790px" nitro-lazy-srcset="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat.png 790w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat-600x294.png 600w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat-300x147.png 300w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat-768x376.png 768w" nitro-lazy-src="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Borat.png" class="wp-image-10345 nitro-lazy" decoding="async" nitro-lazy-empty src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgNzkwIDM4NyIgd2lkdGg9Ijc5MCIgaGVpZ2h0PSIzODciIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyI+PC9zdmc+" /></figure><p>A Remote Access Trojan or RAT is a tool used by <a href="https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/cyber-threat-actor-and-types/" target="_blank">Threat Actors </a>(TAs) to gain full access and remote control on a user&#8217;s system, including mouse and keyboard control, files access, and network resources access.</p><p>During our regular OSINT research, Cyble Research Labs came across a new Remote Access Trojan (RAT) named <em>Borat</em>. Unlike other RATs, the Borat provides Ransomware, DDOS services, etc., to Threat Actors along with usual RAT features, further expanding the malware capabilities.</p> <div id="om-wlravxmwms40sunr2q0v-holder"></div> <template data-nitro-marker-id="a63c15a9ea9c95cbcf4be387544881a9-1"></template> <p>The developer named this RAT &#8216;Borat&#8217; after a black comedy mockumentary film, and the photo used in the RAT is of actor Sacha Baron Cohen, who played the main role in the film Borat. The features claimed by the Borat RAT author are given in Figures 1 &amp; 2 below.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="790" height="474" data-attachment-id="10346" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-1-list-of-features-provided-by-the-borat-rat/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT.png" data-orig-size="790,474" data-comments-opened="0" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT-300x180.png" data-large-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT.png" alt="List of Features provided by the Borat RAT" title="Deep Dive Analysis – Borat RAT 19" sizes="(max-width: 790px) 100vw, 790px" nitro-lazy-srcset="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT.png 790w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT-600x360.png 600w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT-300x180.png 300w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-1-List-of-Features-provided-by-the-Borat-RAT-768x461.png 768w" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 2: Additional Features provided by Borat RAT</figcaption></figure><p>The Borat RAT provides a dashboard to Threat Actors (TAs) to perform RAT activities and also has an option to compile the <a href="https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/what-is-malware/" target="_blank">malware</a> binary for performing DDoS and ransomware attacks on the victim&#8217;s machine, as shown in Figure 3.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="790" height="453" data-attachment-id="10350" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 3: Borat RAT Dashboard</figcaption></figure><h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-technical-analysis">Technical Analysis</h2><p>In this analysis, we will take a look at Borat RAT and its features in detail. The Borat RAT comes as a package which includes builder binary, supporting modules, server certificate, etc., as shown in Figure 4.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img class="wp-element-caption">Figure 5: DLLs used to execute Features</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading">Keylogger</h3><p>The module &#8220;<em>keylogger.exe</em>&#8221; is responsible for monitoring and storing the keystrokes in the victim&#8217;s machine. The below image shows the keyboard-related APIs used by the RAT for keylogging purposes. The captured keystrokes are saved in a file called &#8220;<em>Sa8XOfH1BudXLog.txt</em>&#8221; for exfiltration.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="183" height="242" data-attachment-id="10354" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-6-keyboard-apis/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-6-Keyboard-APIs.png" data-orig-size="183,242" data-comments-opened="0" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="Figure-6-Keyboard-APIs" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-6-Keyboard-APIs.png" data-large-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-6-Keyboard-APIs.png" alt="RAT" title="Deep Dive Analysis – Borat RAT 24" nitro-lazy-src="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-6-Keyboard-APIs.png" class="wp-image-10354 nitro-lazy" decoding="async" nitro-lazy-empty src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMTgzIDI0MiIgd2lkdGg9IjE4MyIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNDIiIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyI+PC9zdmc+" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Figure 6: Keyboard APIs</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading">Ransomware</h3><p>Interestingly, the RAT has an option to deliver a ransomware payload to the victim&#8217;s machine for encrypting users&#8217; files as well as for demanding a ransom. Like other ransomware, this RAT also has the capability to create a ransom note on the victim&#8217;s machine.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="585" height="218" data-attachment-id="10355" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-7-ransomware-note/" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 7: Code to generate Ransom Note</figcaption></figure><p>The RAT has the code to decrypt files in the victim&#8217;s machine once the ransom is paid – as shown below.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="632" height="193" data-attachment-id="10356" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 8: Decryption Method</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-ddos">DDOS</h3><p>This RAT can also disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server by performing a DDOS attack. The below figure shows the code used by RAT for the DDOS attack.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="433" height="212" data-attachment-id="10357" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-9-code-for-ddos-attack/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack.png" data-image-title="Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack-300x147.png" data-large-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack.png" alt="Code for DDoS Attack" title="Deep Dive Analysis – Borat RAT 27" sizes="(max-width: 433px) 100vw, 433px" nitro-lazy-srcset="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack.png 433w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack-300x147.png 300w" nitro-lazy-src="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-9-Code-for-DDoS-Attack.png" class="wp-image-10357 nitro-lazy" decoding="async" nitro-lazy-empty src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgNDMzIDIxMiIgd2lkdGg9IjQzMyIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyMTIiIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyI+PC9zdmc+" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Figure 9: Code for DDoS Attack</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-audio-recording">Audio Recording</h3><p>Borat RAT can record the audio of a computer. Initially, it checks if a microphone is present in the victim&#8217;s machine. If it can find a connected microphone, the RAT records all audio and saves it in a file named <em>micaudio.wav</em>.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="362" height="262" data-attachment-id="10358" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-10-code-for-mic-recording/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-10-Code-for-Mic-Recording.png" data-orig-size="362,262" data-comments-opened="0" 100vw, 362px" nitro-lazy-srcset="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-10-Code-for-Mic-Recording.png 362w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-10-Code-for-Mic-Recording-300x217.png 300w" nitro-lazy-src="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-10-Code-for-Mic-Recording.png" class="wp-image-10358 nitro-lazy" decoding="async" nitro-lazy-empty src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMzYyIDI2MiIgd2lkdGg9IjM2MiIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNjIiIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyI+PC9zdmc+" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Figure 10: Code for Mic Recording</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-webcam-recording">Webcam Recording</h3><p>Borat RAT can capture videos through any webcam present in the victim&#8217;s machine. First, it identifies if a webcam is present in the victim&#8217;s machine, and then it starts recording the video if a webcam is available. &nbsp;</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="349" height="249" data-attachment-id="10359" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-11-webcam-recording/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-11-Webcam-Recording.png" data-orig-size="349,249" data-comments-opened="0" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="Figure-11-Webcam-Recording" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-11-Webcam-Recording-300x214.png" data-large-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-11-Webcam-Recording.png" alt="Webcam Recording" title="Deep Dive Analysis – Borat RAT 29" sizes="(max-width: 349px) 100vw, 349px" nitro-lazy-srcset="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-11-Webcam-Recording.png 349w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-11-Webcam-Recording-300x214.png 300w" nitro-lazy-src="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-11-Webcam-Recording.png" class="wp-image-10359 nitro-lazy" decoding="async" nitro-lazy-empty src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMzQ5IDI0OSIgd2lkdGg9IjM0OSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNDkiIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyI+PC9zdmc+" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Figure 11: Webcam Recording</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-remote-desktop">Remote Desktop</h3><p>This malware takes the remote desktop of the infected machine. It then gives the Threat Actor (TA) the necessary rights to perform activities such as controlling the victim&#8217;s machine, mouse, keyboard, and capturing the screen. Controlling the victim&#8217;s machine can allow TAs to perform several activities such as deleting critical files, executing ransomware in the compromised machine, etc. The below figure shows the functions used by the RAT for performing Remote Desktop activities.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><img width="155" height="121" data-attachment-id="10361" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-12-functions-used-for-taking-remote-desktop/" data-medium-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-12-Functions-used-for-Taking-Remote-Desktop.png" Analysis – Borat RAT 30" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 12: Functions used for performing Remote Desktop Activities</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-reverse-proxy">Reverse Proxy</h3><p>The RAT has code to enable reverse proxy for performing RAT activities anonymously. The TAs can hide their identity using this option while communicating with the compromised servers.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="370" height="199" data-attachment-id="10362" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-13-reverse-proxy-code/" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 13: Reverse Proxy Code</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-device-information">Device Information</h3><p>The RAT collects information from the victim&#8217;s machine, including OS Name, OS Version, System Model, etc. The below figure shows the command used for collecting the information.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="676" height="123" data-attachment-id="10364" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-14-command-used-for-capturing-user-info/" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 14: Command used for Capturing Device Info</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading">Process hollowing</h3><p>Using the RAT, the TAs can inject malicious code into the legitimate processes using the process hollowing technique. The below figure shows the APIs used by the RAT for process hollowing.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="253" height="215" data-attachment-id="10365" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-15-process-hollowing/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-15-Process-Hollowing.png" class="wp-element-caption">Figure 15: Process Hollowing</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-browser-credential-stealing">Browser Credential Stealing</h3><p>Borat RAT can steal cookies, history, bookmarks, saved login credentials from chromium-based browsers like Google Chrome, Edge, etc.<strong> </strong>The below figure shows the functions used by the RAT for stealing browser credentials.</p><figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full"><img width="323" height="248" data-attachment-id="10366" data-permalink="https://cyble.com/blog/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/figure-16-functions-used-for-stealing-browser-credentials/" data-orig-file="https://cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-16-Functions-used-for-Stealing-Browser-Credentials.png" data-orig-size="323,248" data-comments-opened="0" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" Analysis – Borat RAT 34" sizes="(max-width: 323px) 100vw, 323px" nitro-lazy-srcset="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-16-Functions-used-for-Stealing-Browser-Credentials.png 323w, https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-16-Functions-used-for-Stealing-Browser-Credentials-300x230.png 300w" nitro-lazy-src="https://cdn-khlfb.nitrocdn.com/JPtKKXLsjJbtelUWnenRbIbVJOerqPTK/assets/images/optimized/rev-717c118/cyble.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/Figure-16-Functions-used-for-Stealing-Browser-Credentials.png" class="wp-image-10366 nitro-lazy" decoding="async" nitro-lazy-empty src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgMzIzIDI0OCIgd2lkdGg9IjMyMyIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNDgiIHhtbG5zPSJodHRwOi8vd3d3LnczLm9yZy8yMDAwL3N2ZyI+PC9zdmc+" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Figure 16: Functions used for Stealing Browser Credentials</figcaption></figure><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-discord-token-stealing">Discord token Stealing:</h3><p>&nbsp;The RAT also steals Discord tokens and sends the stolen token information to the attacker.</p><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-remote-activities">Remote Activities:</h3><p>The RAT performs the following activities to disturb the victims: Play Audio, Swap Mouse Buttons, Show/hide the Desktop, Show/hide the taskbar, Hold Mouse, Enable/Disable webcam light, Hang System, Monitor Off, Blank screen, etc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><h3 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-conclusion">Conclusion&nbsp;&nbsp;</h3><p>The Borat RAT is a potent and unique combination of Remote Access Trojan, Spyware, and <a href="https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/what-is-ransomware/" target="_blank">Ransomware</a>, making it a triple threat to any machine compromised by it. With the capability to record audio and control the webcam and conduct traditional info stealing behavior, Borat is clearly a threat to keep an eye on. The added functionality to carry out DDOS attacks makes this an even more dangerous threat that organizations and individuals need to look out for. The Cyble Research Team is closely monitoring the RAT&#8217;s actions and will keep informing our clients and people worldwide.</p><h2 class="wp-block-heading">Our Recommendations &nbsp;</h2><p><wbr />We have listed some essential <a href="https://cyble.com/knowledge-hub/cybersecurity/" target="_blank">cybersecurity</a> best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the suggestions given below: &nbsp;</p><ul class="wp-block-list"><li><wbr />Don&#8217;t keep important files in common locations such as the Desktop, My Documents, etc.&nbsp;</li> <li>Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible. &nbsp;</li> <li><wbr />Turn on the automatic software update feature on your computer, mobile, and other connected devices wherever possible and pragmatic. &nbsp;</li> <li><wbr />Use a reputed anti-virus and Internet security software package on your connected devices, including PC, laptop, and mobile. &nbsp;</li> <li><wbr />Refrain from opening untrusted links and email attachments without verifying their authenticity. &nbsp;</li> <li>Conduct regular backup practices and keep those backups offline or in a separate network. &nbsp;</li></ul><h2 class="wp-block-heading" id="h-mitre-att-ck-techniques">MITRE ATT&amp;CK® Techniques&nbsp;</h2><figure class="wp-block-table"><table><tbody><tr><td><strong><wbr />Tactic&nbsp;</strong></td><td><strong><wbr />Technique ID&nbsp;</strong></td><td><strong><wbr />Technique Name&nbsp;</strong></td></tr><tr><td><strong><wbr />Execution&nbsp;</strong></td><td><wbr /><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">T1204</a>&nbsp;</td><td><wbr />User Execution&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Discovery</strong> <strong>&nbsp;</strong></td><td><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">T1518</a></td><td>Security Software Discovery</td></tr><tr><td></td><td><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">T1087</a></td><td>Account Discovery</td></tr><tr><td></td><td><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">T1083</a></td><td>File and Directory
